skill.name: qiskit
skill.description: IBM quantum computing framework. Use when targeting IBM Quantum hardware, working with Qiskit Runtime for production workloads, or needing IBM optimization tools. Best for IBM hardware execution, quantum error mitigation, and enterprise quantum computing. For Google hardware use cirq; for gradient-based quantum ML use pennylane; for open quantum system simulations use qutip.
skill.summary: IBM quantum computing framework. Use when targeting IBM Quantum hardware, working with Qiskit Runtim...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 409 static findings are false positives. The skill contains only markdown documentation with legitimate Python code examples for IBM Qiskit quantum computing. No actual security risks detected.

content.user_title: Build quantum circuits with IBM Qiskit
content.value_statement: Quantum computing enables solving complex optimization, chemistry, and machine learning problems that are intractable for classical computers. Qiskit provides the tools to build quantum circuits, optimize them for IBM hardware, and execute on real quantum processors or simulators.
actual_capabilities: Build quantum circuits with single and multi-qubit gates
Execute circuits on IBM Quantum hardware or local simulators
Implement variational algorithms like VQE and QAOA
Transpile circuits for optimal hardware execution
limitations: Requires IBM Quantum account for hardware access
Quantum hardware has limited coherence time
Jobs queue on shared quantum systems
Noise affects results on current hardware

use_cases.title: Simulate molecular systems
use_cases.description: Calculate ground state energies of molecules using VQE algorithm for drug discovery and materials science

use_cases.title: Solve optimization problems
use_cases.description: Apply QAOA to combinatorial optimization like portfolio optimization, scheduling, and logistics

use_cases.title: Learn quantum computing
use_cases.description: Build quantum circuits, understand superposition and entanglement through hands-on experiments

prompt_templates.title: Create Bell state
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a quantum circuit that generates a Bell state (entangled qubits) and measure the results

prompt_templates.title: Optimize with VQE
prompt_templates.prompt: Use VQE to find the ground state energy of a H2 molecule using the Estimator primitive

prompt_templates.title: Transpile for hardware
prompt_templates.prompt: Transpile my quantum circuit for the ibm_brisbane backend with optimization level 3

prompt_templates.title: Batch execution
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a batch job to run 10 different parameterized circuits on IBM Quantum hardware efficiently

output_examples.input: Create a quantum circuit for Grover's algorithm with 2 qubits
output: Circuit with 2 qubits and 3 gates created

best_practices: Start with simulators before using real quantum hardware
Always transpile circuits for the target backend with optimization
Use sessions for iterative algorithms to reduce queue time
anti_patterns: Running untranspiled circuits directly on hardware
Using too many shots initially - start small and scale up
Ignoring noise and error rates when interpreting results

faq.question: Do I need an IBM Quantum account?
faq.answer: Yes, for real hardware access. Simulators work without authentication.

faq.question: How many qubits are available?
faq.answer: IBM Quantum offers 100+ qubit systems. Free tier provides access to smaller devices for learning.

faq.question: What's the difference between Sampler and Estimator?
faq.answer: Sampler measures qubits and returns bitstrings. Estimator calculates expectation values of observables.

faq.question: How long do quantum jobs take?
faq.answer: Simulator jobs are instant. Hardware jobs queue based on system load, typically minutes to hours.

faq.question: Can I run circuits on other providers?
faq.answer: Yes, Qiskit supports IonQ, Amazon Braket, and other backends through plugins.

faq.question: What algorithms can I implement?
faq.answer: VQE, QAOA, Grover's, quantum machine learning, chemistry simulations, and custom variational algorithms.
